SEARCH
Package edu.ntnu.idi.idatt.services

Class SettingsMenuService

java.lang.Object
edu.ntnu.idi.idatt.services.SettingsMenuService
public class SettingsMenuService extends Object
A service class allowing for a user interface, like TextUserInterface, to interact with a FoodStorage and Cookbook object.

Provides the following functionality:

  • Adding demo data
  • Removing demo data
  • Showing the current date
  • Changing the current date
Since:
0.2
Author:
WilliamHoltsdalen

    • SettingsMenuService

      public SettingsMenuService(FoodStorage foodStorage, Cookbook cookbook, LocalDate currentDate) throws IllegalArgumentException
      Constructs a new settings menu service with the provided food storage, cookbook, and current date.
      Parameters:
      foodStorage - the food storage object to use
      cookbook - the cookbook object to use
      currentDate - the current date object to use
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - if any of the provided objects are null.

    • caseAddDemoData

      public void caseAddDemoData()
      Adds some grocery items to the food storage system. This method is primarily used for testing and demonstration purposes.

      The method creates some grocery items, some with multiple batches with varying expiration dates and some with a single batch. It then adds these grocery items to the food storage. The method also adds some example recipes to the cookbook, some of which can be made using the previously created grocery items.

    • caseRemoveAllData

      public void caseRemoveAllData()
      Removes all grocery items and recipes from the food storage and cookbook.

    • caseShowCurrentDate

      public void caseShowCurrentDate()
      Prints the current date of the application to the console.

    • caseGetNewDate

      public LocalDate caseGetNewDate()
      Gets a new date from the user and returns it as a LocalDate object.

      The method prints a message to the console asking the user to enter a new date in the format yyyy-mm-dd. It then reads the user's input.

      Returns:
      the new date as a LocalDate object
